Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Improving Indoor Air Quality using a Biosilica Based Functional Paint & Coatings Photocatalyst
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a material which when added to commercial paint and coatings can improve indoor air quality by actively removing and degrading Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs). Indoor air quality is generally five times worse than outdoor air quality and VOCs are prevalent in indoor environments, being emitted from typical household items like electronics, cleaners, and flooring. People spend 90% of their lives in indoor environments, making poor indoor air quality a more acute health risk. VOCs are known to cause and worsen allergic diseases such as asthma and eczema, which combined, costs the United States approximately $56 billion in medical spending and lost work productivity every year. Alleviating the discomfort and financial burdens posed by allergic diseases can improve the standard of living of over 60 million affected Americans in the United States. Low- and zero-VOC paints ($9 billion market) are the fastest growing segment of architectural paints ($62 billion market). This technology has the potential to dramatically improve indoor air quality and make everyday living better for children, the elderly, and adults suffering from allergic diseases.

The intellectual merit of this project will further the understanding of using diatoms in conjunction with a photocatalyst to harvest light as an energy source for the removal of pollutants from environments. Diatoms have been shown to increase the collection of ultraviolet, blue and red wavelengths of light. As a substrate for photocatalysts which utilize these wavelengths, diatoms may provide a superior light collection capability, increasing the effectiveness of photocatalysts. The proposed aim is to show an increase in the photocatalytic rate of VOC degradation which could help to make metal oxide photocatalysis a more viable option for air treatment. The proposed research makes the following contributions: 1) advancement of efficient visible light photocatalysis with a diatom-based additive; 2) understanding integration of photocatalytic paint additives into base paint and coatings mixtures, optimized for minimal paint substrate degradation and maximal photocatalytic degradation of indoor air-pollutants; and 3) long-term improvement of indoor air quality. Overall it is expected that this Phase I will show diatoms, as substrates, can increase the rate of photocatalysts up to two times under typical irradiation sources. This project targets cleaner indoor environments through pollutant removal activity without increased energy usage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a significant threat to both human health and global climate change. Many VOCs are known carcinogens and are off-gassed by typical consumer products we use and live within our homes and building structures (e.g. schools, offices, hospitals). This makes VOCs a common contaminant from the indoor air we breathe. In addition, it was recently reported that the largest source of fossil fuel-based VOCs in urban environments is derived from consumer use of glues, paints, cosmetics and cleaners. VOCs are typically considered to be many times more potent green-house gasses than CO2. Removing and destroying VOCs will lead to a healthier and cleaner indoor and outdoor environment. Diatomix is working to incorporate a VOC destroying technology into consumer applications to provide a benefit to mankind.

In the Phase I project titled, ?Improving Indoor Air Quality using a Biosilica Based Functional Paint & Coatings Additive?, Diatomix demonstrated the feasibility to add our innovative technology to carpet cleaning solutions to remove and destroy VOCs from interior environments. Carpet cleaning solutions was targeted as the application due to strong customer interest and the large market size potential (segmented available market). On the other hand, the wall paint market proved too cost prohibitive and the interest from customer discovery efforts was lukewarm. 

Phase 1 tests demonstrated that Diatomix?s additive was feasibly able to destroy VOCs using typical indoor lighting, including LED light. This clearly shows the ability to use visible light an important step for our light driven catalyst. Prior to Phase 1, Diatomix already had shown excellent performance with compact fluorescent and window light. The mechanism by which the Diatomix technology destroys VOCs is similar to the Earth?s natural process done in the upper atmosphere with UV light, i.e. light that does not reach the Earth?s surface. Enabling the same cleaning process without needing UV light will greatly enhance removing the increased VOCs levels present in today?s indoor and outdoor environments. 

Following extensive coating analysis in the Phase I work, the concept that substrate shape can affect the performance of Diatomix technology in coatings was validated. In particular, Diatomix was able to find optimally shaped diatoms, the support structure for the VOC-destroying light driven catalyst, for different coatings applications including paint and carpet cleaners.

Finally, Diatomix was able to show that the technology can last for years as an active VOC destroying technology. This is important for applications beyond cleaners. Diatomix believes this technology will be employed in manufactured home furnishings, such as carpet, wall paper and cement, as well as long term coatings such as paint in the future and is confident the technology can continue to remove and destroy VOCs for long-term applications. 

Diatomix?s VOC destroying catalyst evaluated in this project have an exceptional opportunity to both improve indoor air quality as well as reduce greenhouse-gasses to curb climate change. The catalyst developed by Diatomix has excellent and novel characteristics that make it a stand-out performer for indoor environments. Diatomix?s technology will assist in giving the U.S. a competitive advantage in the competitive arena of functional air quality improvement coatings.
